author: sky.cactus
content: Would it be reasonable for me to merge this change as an editor, rather than an author, given that the authors are no longer responsive?  https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/3099

author: sky.cactus
content: It was born out of https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/3025.  Perhaps we should just not merge either and wait for this EIP to go stale so it can be moved to abandoned (or whatever we decided to call that state)?

author: gcolvin
content: Why do want to remove this section?

author: sky.cactus
content: Someone submitted a PR to update it, which triggered a discussion about using EIPs as a place to store maintained lists of things.

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe there was general agreement among the editors that we definitely do not have the manpower to maintain lists of things in EIPs, so it is better to keep the EIP content constrained to things that are unlikely to change with time (meaning no mutable lists of things).

author: gcolvin
content: I guess I missed the discussion.  I've been busy trying to earn a living. The old "rough consensus and running code" principle from the IETF and "codify existing practice" principle from ANSI would indicate that actual implementations of EIPs are very useful, even though understood to be mutable.  So I'd like to reopen that discussion.

author: gcolvin
content: And separately, I've got some ancient proposals for EVM improvements that I have not abandoned, but the simple fact is that it took five years to get core dev consensus on getting the EVM to 1970 level functionality, could take more years to get it to 1990, and still more years more to get it to 2020.  So they could be in a "Schrödinger's cat" status for a long time.  Where do they fit in our current scheme?

author: sky.cactus
content: You can progress the EIP to final without any core dev agreeing.

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree implementations are useful things.  I disagree that all useful things should live inside EIPs.

author: gcolvin
content: Except they (my EIPS) are really Drafts that will need to evolve as the world changes underneath them.

author: sky.cactus
content: Bitcoin solved this by having a separate SLIP process for "lists of things" (essentially).

author: sky.cactus
content: It was agreed that an author can move any abandoned EIP back into its previous state at will.  So worst case scenario if we had some bot auto-moving EIPs to abandoned the author could just move the EIP back without any negative pushback.

author: sky.cactus
content: I personally would consider that "working as intended", though others may disagree.

author: gcolvin
content: OK, then I'll just object to the name Abandoned on that one.

author: gcolvin
content: On implementations, I really want a way to refer to them, even if they are prototypes.

author: gcolvin
content:
I propose "Schrödinger" rather than "Abandoned."

Or "Heisenberg" since it is his Uncertainty Principle.

author: gcolvin
content: Not all useful things, but implementations are directly relevant.  In evaluating an EIP I very much want to know whether and how easily it can be implemented.  I don't want to google the web trying to find an implementation.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the actual name isn't abandoned, but I don't remember what it actually is at the moment...

author: sky.cactus
content: Stagnant is what we ended up with (just looked it up).

author: gcolvin
content: Like a pond stinking of rotten algae.

author: 0xraino
content: Dank.

author: gcolvin
content: I really prefer the ANSI approach of having only three statuses - proposed, accepted for the next TR or Standard, and actually published in the next PR or Standard.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think functionally we are not actually that far from that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Draft => Review => Final are the primary 3 states that the *vast* majority of EIPs are always in.

author: sky.cactus
content: In theory Stagnant may become a very high volume state I suppose.
